video.title: Persona 5: The Phantom X | Fully Ramblomatic

captions.text:
Persona 5: The Phantom X? More like Perso, 
no, no, no, no, no, no, no, no, no, no, no,

no, no. 5. This is normally the point where I&#39;d 
have a dig at Atlus for once again putting off

finally having to announce Persona 6 instead 
of another dicksickening spinoff or remaster,

but there is a point when a bit of cheeky 
tease and denial becomes flat-out denial,

which not coincidentally is also the first stage 
of the grieving process. I&#39;ve been following The

Phantom X since it was announced, and the moment 
I knew it was a fucking free to play Gacha game,

I was thinking, &quot;Please don&#39;t succeed. Please 
don&#39;t be fucking successful. Don&#39;t GTA Online

this bitch; give a great single-player 
franchise the excuse to not make another

game for 13 fucking years.&quot; But we all knew 
it was gonna succeed, didn&#39;t we? Because

those fucking whales just can&#39;t get enough of 
watching anime girls&#39; tight sweaters jiggle

almost imperceptibly for a fraction of a second 
because they turned around too quick. Still,

as someone who really likes Persona 5 and has 
yet to be won over by a Gacha game—in the way

this Josef Stalin fella still hasn&#39;t won me 
over on this whole &quot;gulag&quot; concept—I felt

the need to try it because this was the best 
chance Gacha games were ever going to get.

Theoretically, anyway. In practice, this was 
like having to watch a famous actor I respect

shilling their new fucking cryptocoin. Still, I 
was impressed by the initial trailer because it&#39;s

undeniably progressive of Atlus to finally have 
another Persona game with a female protagonist.

And then I played the game and realized, &quot;Oh, it&#39;s 
just a dude with a girly haircut.&quot; Got me again,

anime. Should&#39;ve realized in anime, a girly 
haircut only becomes a girl&#39;s haircut if it

looks like it takes three hours of work and 
two cans of fluorescent spray paint. Anyway,

Phantom X is a story running somewhat 
in parallel to that of Persona 5,

except instead of playing a dude who&#39;s been 
wrongly accused and disenfranchised and pushed

to the brink very satisfyingly turning 
things around on a corrupted society,

we play a dude. &quot;Sounded like there was going 
to be more to that sentence, Yahtz.&quot; Yes,

that was the gag, thank you. A dude. A dude who 
lives in a house. Who teleports to the Metaverse

basically at random and swiftly acquires 
an animal sidekick, a Persona awakening,

and a weird bossy lady in a blue outfit as part 
of the standard Metaverse induction package.

Considering how well written Persona 5 
was, it&#39;s really stark comparing that

to how fucking weaksauce the characterization is 
in Phantom X. The main villain of the first act,

for example. You wanna know how the game 
establishes he&#39;s been corrupted by the

forces of darkness? Brace yourself. He barges 
past people on the subway a lot. No, really,

that&#39;s it. And they make a real fucking meal 
out of it. He&#39;s standing there, going, &quot;Yes,

I barged into those people, and I&#39;ll do 
it again, and I&#39;ll just keep claiming it

was an accident, bwa ha ha ha. I&#39;m evil and 
no one can ever stop me, least of all you,

even if you invade my subconscious while 
dressed as a highwayman from the future.&quot;

And the plot flat out informs us that if we don&#39;t 
go inside his mental realm and steal his heart,

then he&#39;s literally going to nudge a baby to 
death. I swear I&#39;m not making this up. Besides

that, the first act plays rather blatantly like 
a truncated version of the first act of Persona

5 except it&#39;s baseball instead of volleyball and 
the Ann and Ryuji arcs are rolled into a single

support character who has to both champion the 
injured best friend AND avenge the ruined sporting

career; one wonders how she finds the time to 
eat her depression cornflakes in the morning.

Ah, so it&#39;s an alternative universe version 
of Persona 5, is it? I might&#39;ve thought so

if the established Persona 5 characters weren&#39;t 
constantly popping their heads around the door for

fan service. And your interactions with them are 
always so fucking cringey. &quot;Who are you? Are you

a Phantom Thief? Me too! What effortless chemistry 
we have.&quot; It&#39;s like reading a story from a teenage

girl&#39;s dream journal about her hanging out with 
Harry Styles. Yes, that&#39;s as contemporary as my

references get. So, we acquire party members in 
the story through the traditional method—villain

of the moment victimizes prodigious young 
person, young person confronts villain&#39;s shadow

in the Metaverse, moment of self-realization, 
scream, bloodily pull off own face, handshake,

certificate, commemorative photograph, etc. But 
then it&#39;s also a Gacha game, so there&#39;s also other

party members we acquire from pulling the lever 
on the slot machine, who are also Phantom Thieves

with names and Personas but who have no story 
introduction and we know fuck all about. Some

of them appear to be characters from the story 
we haven&#39;t met yet, and others are just randos,

standing around on the fringe of the party, 
occasionally going, &quot;Oh, look, a treasure&quot; because

there&#39;s an obvious glowing chest in the room, 
sweating bullets that we&#39;ll ask awkward questions.

&quot;Who am I and how the fuck did I get here? 
Uhhhhh... Oh, look, a treasure. Let me spin

around very fast to point at it, jiggle jiggle.&quot; 
This is the game trying to have it both ways.

It&#39;s got Persona-style activities like working the 
convenience store or hanging out with your mates,

and they ostensibly advance time, but there&#39;s 
no time crunch element. No deadlines. Find a

locked chest in the dungeon, who cares? Just 
instantly teleport home, craft some lockpicks,

do the gardening, do nine side stories, and go 
back to the dungeon at your leisure, and the game

won&#39;t give a metric half-squirt of shit. But then 
of course I reached the end of the first dungeon,

and the game was like, &quot;Next is the boss fight, 
and by the way, you&#39;re eight levels behind;

better grind that up before continuing.&quot; And 
thus does the insidious pissing about begin.

&#39;Cause the best way to level up is to grind 
out random fights for crafting materials,

and that only levels YOU up. You wanna level 
your party members, you&#39;ve gotta manually shove

a load of Experience Gems into them, possibly 
with a funnel and a spoon. And if you run out

of Stamina Gems, don&#39;t worry, you can buy more 
with your Poor Financial Decision-Making Gems,

which you can buy for actual money from 
the shop. Not that shop, the other shop.

The theory that live service games deliberately 
design their menus to be as confusing as possible

in the hopes you get dizzy and accidentally 
drop your social security number is basically

confirmed, I think. Why else would a game have 
different menus for Goals, Contracts, Missions,

and Rewards, all of which have different fucking 
stuff? This is doubly heartbreaking considering

one of Persona 5&#39;s most characteristic features 
is its efficient and beautifully designed menus.

It&#39;s like hearing that your favorite singer 
got throat cancer. And he got it from singing

a song you really hate. &#39;Cause all the 
lyrics are about asking people for money.

Urgh. Every now and again, I&#39;ll see a glimpse 
of the real Persona 5, a story moment here,

a thumpin&#39; bit of music there, the odd satisfying 
battle sequence rewarding strategic planning,

even if One More actions can now only be 
generic attacks and we aren&#39;t allowed to

pick the target &#39;cause I guess making the 
combat interesting was less important than

directing us to buy Interesting Combat Gems. 
But it&#39;s all flayed skin being worn by a serial

killer. It&#39;s not even that; it&#39;s the skin 
lying torn and discarded on bare cement.

Left there for us to pick through like we&#39;re 
searching a puddle of sick for the last good

unclaimed chunks of half-digested carrot. 
I did tell you to bring a cocktail stick.
